reviewText:
REVIEW OF RECENT GAME CHANGES by ALVARAKK, 16/01/2014 (updated 09/09/2014)

MY BACKGROUND
I started playing DnT with first released on Facebook about one year ago and I have been playing regularly since. I was admitted to play-testing group and granted access to the developer's test-server. I am a pro-player, with some 5,000+ ranked PvP matches and reached top 3 ranking position consecutively in the last three PvP seasons and last stats show me at highest KDR (Kill-to-Death Ratio) in the game. I am currently ranked #9 in PvP season 4.

Trust me when I tell you, Dragons and Titans is NOT WORTH your time or money. .

* The game patch of 01/04/2014 introduced lock-on auto-aim which drastically changed the movement controls in the game, made several dragon combos obsolete, and completely removed the need for players to learn and master their maneuvering and aiming skills. In the recent months Wyrmbyte carried on to dumb-down the game in hopes of attracting more players -- ultimately failing in that too as player numbers in Multiplayer PvP at peak times of the day stand at around 400 now (compare that to DOTA2 or LOL where you have tens of thousands). They reduced the competitive aspect of PvP into a witless and uninspired routine of holding down the fire button and moving your mouse back and forth to control the firing range. Teamplay and coordination have been rendered obsolete in lieu of a contest where players compete only on who can dish out more damage fastest. The advantages of precise timing and tactical thinking have been stripped out of competitive PvP and matches have descended into routine of blindly rushing the opponents in the hopes of out-damaging them. Outcomes are primarily decided on what combos individual players picked up, which is random and unpredictable.

* The update of 10/06/2014 continued the steady decline changing the mechanics of the matching-system.
-Teams are now truly and completely random and unpredictable. The most shocking change is that the pre-match setup stage was removed, which is where you used to be able to get a minute's worth of chat with the 4 teammates the game picked up for you and discuss combos and tactics. Now, you are plunged directly into match with no opportunity to plan and prepare.
-To make things worse, players can not choose or predict what map is going to be played (there are 3, each a completely different mode of play), so they don't get can't pick a suitable combo and enter matches blind and ill-prepared.
- The other drastic change was that the restrictions on selection of dragon and weapons was removed. In the past players could only pick a weapon and dragon that was not already in use by one of their teammates and generally whoever was first to click it, got it and mostly refused to relinquish it. Whilst this caused a lot of heated pre-match bickering and some truly foul behavior between teammates, it also forced players to think about what combos best supported and complemented that of the rest of their team. This is no longer the case and players have foregon support roles and invariably stick with the cookie-cutter combos that give them the biggest DPS advantage. This change has also taken away from the formerly enjoyable variety offered by DnT 's myriad of choices, and along with it the need for new players to familiarize themselves with all weapons/dragons and take time to learn their strengths and weaknesses. To illustrate the point, most matches now include a bland carbon-copy selection of combos, with most players equipping Winter Floe and Skyburst and riding either an Imperial or Gemtalon.
- In the same stroke, Wyrmbyte hammered-in the last nail to DnT's coffin by preventing players from teaming-up with more than one player. Thus, they dashed all hopes of players being able to form into clans or guilds and fighting it out in Full 5v5s. We are now left to suffer matches that are little more than a frustrating lottery and where skill and experience have scant impact on the outcome.

OTHER ISSUES
Disappointingly, Wyrmbyte continues to ignore feedback from their play-testers and experienced players alike, resulting in a completely unbalanced PvP and proving to the gaming industry that their diminutive team is just too amateurish and does not have what it takes to deliver an enjoyable gaming experience. Also characteristic of Wyrmbyte is their complete inability to improve and fix their game code, where the blight of bugs seems completely out of control. Major bugs that have been in existence at the early stages of the beta testing, persist still with no indication from Wyrmbyte as to whether they have any plans to sort them out. The introductions of STEAM client failed to stem the constant flow of speed-hacking cheaters that continue to abuse the game and take all fun out of it for genuine players. On top of that, new game issues and exploits are cropping up at an alarming rate and each new game update from Wyrmbyte is a guaranteed source of new and persistent problems.

CONCLUSIONS
Somewhere along the way Dragons and Titans drifted off-course and lost all sight of becoming a balanced and challenging 5v5 arena and is now being precariously carried-away into the chaotic waters of a mediocre free-for-all. The spectacular dragon themes and above-standard quality of art alone fail to sustain player interest and unsurprisingly their numbers are dwindling daily. This game had promising potential in its early life, which was however ultimately squandered by Wyrmbyte who failed time and again to improve and polish their product.

RECOMMENDATION
This game will disappoint and frustrate you. Stay away from it.
There are better free MOBAs out there.

UPDATE
As of 09/09/2014 there is still no option to choose map or predict which one will be played. No pre-match team screen to discuss tactics. Speed-hackers continue to dominate the game and the cheaters are completely out of control. Whoever in Wyrmbyte is making decisions on game development should hang their head in shame and just leave the gaming industry forever. So much fail.

Don't get baited.

This game has the worst tutorial ever created. The controls are clunky and you have to jump through hoops to play 5v5 pvp.

It is terribly unpolished and not worth the time. Dragons don't move by the standard right click to location they follow the mouse cursor, you press spacebar to fly backwards like a hummingbird and each dragon gets 2 skills only. You bring a weapon from the cash shop into battle that gives you 2 other abilities.

There are tons of dragons to choose from but the game doesn't feel like it has a core element. There are dragons that clearly outrank others in terms of innate abilities. The games in game graphics are worse than they are in screenshots. The screenshots for this game seem to have been touched up to give it a better presentation.

Comparing this to other MOBA/ARTS games out there, I rather play any other one than this.

Edit: I have played a couple of multiplayer games as you can see to my play time; it’s really a cluster♥♥♥♥ of things going on. The Map isn't that intuitive given the movement limitations and controls.

I've used a golem type dragon that fires boulders that ricochet when they hit an enemy or wall. Together with a Purple rod that allowed me to set mines and automatically teleport me to the nearest gold roost.

During many exchanges I noticed players talk in the lobby about the weapon they purchased from the shop given them a distinct advantage.

The main problem with control is the fact that all of your abilities directly are targeted at wherever your mouse cursor is. What causes the rift is that your dragon also follows the cursor religiously for movement. So when fighting you have to constantly be flying backward or standing still to get the 8 way directional aiming to do what you want.

There are tons of dragons to pick from and weapons to accompany them, variety is good. With the already oversaturation of the ARTS/MOBA market I can't recommend this game over anything else in its current state.

Before I say anything else, let me be clear about one thing.  This game IS good for someone who is new to MOBAs.  Playing around on it can be fun, and you can have a good time just pounding on the computers if you want.  I like the way that you can mix the activatable abilities of your dragon by swapping in different weapons.  It's a feature I haven't seen in the other MOBAs I have played.  The weapons usually don't provide abilities that are broken with any specific dragons, so the balancing on it isn't too bad.

However, if you are familiar with MOBAs, you'll only really play this one when you don't have access to your favorites.  The monetization of this game leaves a lot to be desired.  I get that they are trying to make money off of their product, but they didn't have to make it into some sort of CCG for dragons and weapons.  It's nice that they provide a daily login bonus, and that every 5 days you get another free (random) dragon, but the amount of gems that it takes to get the booster pack of dragons or weapons is pretty high, and you don't even have the option of picking out a specific one of either.  They love to point out how many gems you would have earned after each match if you had just been willing to spend the money on a Titan Pass, too, which I find to be very annoying.

All in all, this game shows a lot of potential, but it's just not living up to it for those of us who are already familiar with MOBAs.

Pay to win? More like Play to win!

Personally I think Dragons and Titans is a lovely little MOBA. I agree that it can't really compare to games like Dota and League of Legends, but the potential is certainly there.

The most common complaints I've seen in reviews are that the game would be Pay to Win and that the controls are clunky. One review even stated you can't attack and fly at the same time.

I find these arguments unfounded. All dragons are quite balanced so buying more with money hardly gives you an advantage. The tutorial gives you the crystals(the in game currency) to buy a dragon pack and a weapons pack, both containing 3 random dragons and 3 random weapons respectively. Through playing PVP or the single player campaign you can earn more crystals. I've had pvp games in which I earned about 300 crystals and you need 2500 for a weapons pack and 5000 for a dragons pack.

Further more there are a bunch of free to play dragons and weapons to choose from in PVP battles. These dragons and weapons rotate every other week between all the dragons and weapons available.

As for the keybinding, I will admit that its hard to get used to at first, but it's hardly clunky. Once you get the feel for it you'll be twisting and turning and breathing whatever your dragons breathing down on your foes. Flying and attacking at the same time is easy to do, some dragons even have homing attacks that will find your target no matter which direction you're facing.

There's 3 pvp maps with different game modes and the levels are well designed. Overall the PVP element is the best part of the game as it should be, but the single player campaign is a nice add on.

The single player campaign allows you to unlock dragons. Now I've seen a complaint about that in one of the reviews that you would need to clear 150 levels before unlocking the dragon. In truth you only need to play through every level once to unlock the dragon. But I agree that the difficulty is really high even when played in recruit mode. You'll die a lot, get frustrated a lot and if you're anything like me you'll just give up on it and go '♥♥♥♥ it I'm sticking to pvp'

But the thing I really like about this game is that you can endlessly combine weapons and dragons. Meaning that you could face off against a dragon with a weapon that shoots arrows one time and then be faced with that same dragon with the ability to drop mines and teleport the next time you face it. It also means that you can choose your own style of play.

Further more, the more you play a dragon or weapon, the more experience is awarded to them, allowing them to advance ranks and become faster and more powerfull. So really, the more you play the more powerful your dragons and weapons get and the more likely you are to win!

And if that isn't reason enough to give it a try. There's one argument that is sure to at least get me playing

Its a Dragon MobA!

reviewText: To be honest, I wasn't expecting much from Dragons and Titans as I am not a huge fan of MOBAs, but I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. The abundance of great looking dragons and various weapons provides for many unique playstyles and really keeps the game interesting. I also personally love the way the items work in this game compared to other MOBAs in that you don't need to constantly return to the base to upgrade or purchase new items; item selection is done before the match begins. This allows for much less downtime and smooths the learning curve quite a bit. My only complaint with Dragons and Titans is that targeting can be annoying and very difficult to control. Some dragons also seem overpowered.. but that is to be expected and overall, I was satisfied with the level of balance between the dragons that I saw. All in all, it's a great free MOBA and you should definitely check it out!

reviewText:
This is a great game with a rocky beginning - I highly suggest you get through the tutorial and play at least 2 or 3 of the 5v5 PVP battles before passing judgment.  In addition to the cool lore and novelty of a moba in which you fly on a dragon's back, there are several key features that I think are innovative and make this game different from the rest of the pack:

* Pressing spacebar lets you move backwards but still face forward, which makes for some interesting mechanics in outmanuevering your opponents.  Breathing fire on your opponent while backpedaling is also just fun!
* The typical 4 abilities of most MOBAs are split - you get 2 from your dragon and 2 from your weapon.  This means you can create a huge number of combinations of abilities, flexibility which is really cool especially once you unlock a lot of dragons and weapons.  In other words, the same dragon can be played in vastly different ways depending on weapon choice.
* The matches are typically fast, like 10-20 minutes, which is nice - I don't have to dedicate as much time to drop in and play a game here and there.
* There are no in-match items to buy.  I love this becuase I don't have to memorize a huge inventory to play the game (or spend time sitting there agonizing over my item choice).  I can just concentrate on the game itself.
* There is much less focus on killing minions, and much more focus on fighting the other players dragons.

The art is beautiful but a bit rough around the edges, and the interface is serviceable but could be a bit more intuitive.

At its core, Dragons and Titans is a great game that does key things differently from the MOBA crowd.  It fits great for me as a game I can drop in and play here and there without having to read tomes to catch up on what I missed or be screamed at for being a newb every moment when I play again and forget item builds...

It may not draw you in with its tutorial, but give it a chance to shine and it does not disappoint.

reviewText:
Fun little moba, while most have you wait and bide your time, This one throws you head first into the action and matches quickly start out with a massive team fight. Games usually take between 10-20 minutes so its easy to do a few matches.

As for shop items, Dragons and weapons are easily buyable with ingame money (Crystals) which are not to hard to farm up, or real money for a quick boost. Dragons come in packs of 3 random ones, but you can buy specific ones for real money. Vanity items such as skins and avatars are bought with real money.

Apon starting a game you will choose one dragon and one weapon, all dragons have a general boost to character health and mana, as well as gold collection. Your dragon selection will modify your first 2 abilities as well as general stats such as speed, attack power, as well as attacks. The weapon you choose provides your last 2 attacks and each weapon is highly varied in which attacks it offers as well as utilities. Some weapon offer additional attacks, while others are passive buffs and still others boost in movement.  You also have 2 spells avalible to use.

Dragons and Titans offers several game modes including a single player adventure mode which allows you to earn special rewards. All of the Pvp game modes involve freeing your titan from the enemies, but each mode involves somewhat different methods to go through. Gold is avalible to collect and return in all game modes. Gold offers experience as well as in some game modes provides additional benefits.

Moba involves traveling through a wide and open map with various areas to explore. Unlike standard mobas this one does not have specific lanes, or a Jungle" to explore. Collecting gold here and returning it to the hoards here will summon a chaos titan who is a powerful boss creature that heals allies and shreds towers. Aid your titan to help it push to the heart of your enemies base. Apon summoning a titan
date: all progress towards your enemies titan is lost so gather gold often to ensure you're the one with the advantage.\n\nControl points has 5 control points that when captured slowly weaken the enemies titan cage shields. Gold here just offers experience and no added benefits. Once a control point is captured
recommended: you can teleport to it from the hoard as well as function as a gold drop off.\n\nAram is an all random mode that is just one quick fast paced lane where all dragons are randomly selected for the user while weapons can still be chosen freely. Gold is automatically dropped off and when the bar fills fully it will fire a set of 3 balistae to deal massive damage to anything in the path
hoursPlayed: This damage is enough to oneshot most dragons.\n\nOver all Dragons and titans is a nice fast paced moba that is still in active development. It stands differently to League of Legends as well as Dota 2

reviewText:
Dragons and Titans - отличная представительница жанра MOBA. Отличная, потому что своя, ни откуда не содраная, что я порой замечаю в некоторых играх сего жанра. Отличная, потому что принесла мне много новых впечетлений, и по-моему не только мне. Одним словом у неё довольно много плюсво:
+ Тут есть драконы, много драконов! Все любят драконов!
+ Именно в этой игре я первый раз столкнулся с non-target системой боя в данном жанре.
+ Ты можешь донатить сколько твоей душонке угодно, но это никак не повлеяет на твою архизашибенность в этой игре. Донат тут помогает быстраее получить новых дракончиков и цацки, которые ты тягаешь в своих ручонках, он служат как дополнительные способности.
+ Есть несколько режимов игры, и ни одни не похож на режимы из тех MOBA игр в которые я играл, за исключением Battle или Ballist alley, у меня с памятью плоховато.
+ Неплохо сделана и сюжетная линия со связаными с ней челенджами!
+ Интуитивное управление, понятно с первых минут игры.
+ Приятная графика, нет, не как в кукурузисе или даенг лайте, а как должна быть в игре про драконов.
Но в любой игре можно найти минусы:
- Меня совсем не порадовало то, что в пати можно взять только одного человека.
- Игра периодически зависает, и не на время, а на совсем, но оживает после её ребута.
- Моя мятежноя душонка сильно взбунтовалась, когда я понял, что драконов нельзя покупать по одному. И если в начале   игры не возмутило, т.к. я был рад любому дракону, то когда я понял, принцип действия всех дракош, наступила печаль.
- Порой, кажется, что накопить на новую пачку дракош невозможно.
- Русский перевод не очень корректен, так сказать, но радует уже и то, что он есть.
В общем и целом игра хороша. Моя оценка 8/10.

P.S. Вложить деньги в игру стоит, если не для удавлетворения драконьих потребностей, то для поддержки разработчиков, они вам игру бесплатно предоставили, как ни как.

reviewText:
MOBA based on dragons, weapons and elements.

Choose to either play the campaign or jump into games VS real people or bots. You pick a dragon of your choice, being different from each other and depending on its element, will give you two unique abilities - Q and R. Q is your main attack, it cost little mana and normally has a small cooldown, W is your secondary attack, usually if your dragon has an escape or damage reduction ability, its situated here.

Now for the weapon, you get to pick an item of your choice to wield into battle, giving you the other two abilities, your E and R. Depending on what type of build you wish to play, these items will give different skills. Example is a mace that gives massive mana regen as a passive, your E, while the R is a dmg ability. Some items are strickly support, some are healing, some are damage and some are a mix of both. This allows you to play the same dragon with different weapons to create completely new builds and playstyles.

There are no items in this game, the gold you collect from killing enemy players and minions is stored on your person and requires you to return back to base and dump the gold in a pile. This then gives you experience depending on how much gold you had stored away.

Three different gamemodes, ARAM, normal MOBA with three lanes and a zone capture gametype.

You begin the game with 3 random dragons and 3 random weapons, so if you don't get what you want, you will need to play a bunch of games for crystals to buy the desired items or pay real money for bundles.

The objective of both the ARAM and normal 3 lane MOBA is to destroy the turrets linked to a statue, then destroy the statue to deactivate a forcefield that weakens your dragon and slows down his speed. Do this several times until you reach your titan and release it from its prison, (attack the main objective, like the nexus in LoL) and the game is over.

I play League of Legends a lot of the time, so that satiates all my MOBA needs, but I do recommend trying it out, its free and pretty fun if your willing to get the hang of it.

Personal Rating: 3/5

Other than that, no real problems with this game.

reviewText:
First the bad stuff:
-EXPENSIVE game if you are gonna use euros to unlock dragons... you can unlock random dragons but you don't know if you will some of the old dragons you got (coming back to that later) or someone new to test.
Also buying a single dragon costs just as much as buying 3 random ones and you get the first rank of the dragon... not the 3rd rank (something that is a really bad deal for what? 3-5 euro).

-There are 3 diffrent ranks between the dragons that increases armor (or hp or whatever) and movement speed... something that means if you meet someone that you just as great against... and you got the first rank and he got the 2nd or 3rd rank of the same dragon... he will win because of his small stat gain... I do love the dragon ranks... but it would have been enough with just the graphical coolness of higher rank dragons... Removing stats on diffrent mastery ranks would be really smart...

-The lore and the dialogs feels like are written by a 5 year old... some of the dialog is so bad and some of the missions feel so stupid that I some times started to wonder why I even tested this game at all...
There are mobs in the act 1 missions that are so annoying... like some ghosts that are protecting some crypts you need to destroy... They all just fly towards you and push you out of position and you take damage without the monsters having any animation at all... almost like you thought it was made by an indie game company without any animators... or any interested programmers to actually make a decent mob script...

-Every time you complete an act you get an dragon... The main problem with that is that the act is so long and the amount of gems (that you can use for unlocking more dragons) is so low... you rather feel like playing lol or any other type of moba game because you progress a lot faster in those games.. But, yeah you can also get mastery on the dragon by doing ALL the challanges on every mission in every act! That's 15 reruns of each of the missions you actually would'nt want to play in the first place! 15!!!!!!

-there is no way to do practice games vs bots to try out dragons. I know it's a free rotation every week but yeah. If you want a player to waste 5 euro on one dragon you better let him have a taste of what he is gonna buy or else the player will find something else to waste his money on... and that won't be anything related to this game... unless he buys shyvanna from lol... because she is a dragon thingie... same with Ao in smite... or whatever that chinese dragon's name is...


I felt that these things needed to be highlighted in the review because these are pretty annoying and game/mood breaking things that I have noticed so far in the game and it's the first impression a new player meet in this game.


Good things about the game.
-The movement system is quite functional. easy to move around and holding space makes you fly backwards while you can use your skills in the direction you are pointing... It may give a good feeling in pvp.

-Game looks ok/good graphical. Of course there could be some major improvements in the graphics... but I liked it...

-There are tons of interesting and cool looking dragons... gives you the interest of wanting to try everyone of them... To bad there is'nt a 20 dragon bundle pack of rank 2 dragons or whatever...

-The way you get to chose your two first skills by the dragon type and the two other remaining skills by chosing items is actually really well done. I liked it a lot... To bad I will use my time playing smite instead untill they manage to do some major changes in how their greedy minds works...

-I am pretty certain that if you play this game for a month or two... all the negative things I wrote won't really be an issue as you will have unlocked a few dragons just by gems and dices that the game will be worthwhile to game full time. That and the horrible campaign will be long gone memories that you would never have to touch with your mind ever the f... again....

reviewText:
Less then a year out and it is doing well.  I won't say the game is perfect because it's not and I won't say the game is complete because with this type of game you don't finish you continue to grow.

There is a great selection of dragons and weapons to choose from.  You have the traditional moba archtypes of bruiser, support, tank etc.  The types of dragons you can play with is varied and makes the lore interesting.  You have your elementals, traditional European and Oriental style dragons, Golems/machines and more.

Good or bad right now when you join the PVP you are taken to one of three maps: ARAM (All random all mid), Control points, and lastly the more traditional attack the base map.

The Community is largely supportive but due to the currently small player base the match making system puts mismatched skill levels together.  More detrimental is the systems will stack the teams with 3 or 4 high ranking players on one team.

The introductory levels to the game are well thought out and get you quickly into the action and show you where everything is located.  If you forget or haven't come across something yet the community is ready to help answer questions.  Always improving and moving in the direction from good to great.  I hope you give it a whirl and find it as enjoyable as I have.

reviewText:
I believe this will be the first review written by someone who has more than a few menial hours invested in the game. I've played a season and a half, last season I was ranked somewhere in the top 50.

To begin with, this game has epic potential, I discovered it by chance via fb apps and after many hours and a terrible kdr (kill death ratio) , I grew to love it. The mechanics, the community and the competitive spirit. Making my way up the ranks I watched in awe at how good the pro players were and worked at getting a decent, well thought out rune set and understand the strengths and weaknesses of the multitude of dragons and weapons available. The negative reviews here were likely written by people who failed to grasp, that this, like most moba's, has a learning curve and that you need to adapt to get any joy from the game. How many of us kicked off Dota2 or LoL and mastered controls and gameplay immediately?

Last season the game suffered immense balance issues with the release of a terribly OP'd dragon and weapon. This was fixed, somewhat at the start of season 4 and a great many dragons were improved.

reviewText:
If you are planning to try this game or thinking of getting Titan Pass, please read the following. Also notice the number of game hours I have (~960 hours).

This game is very badly broken. There are far too many OP combos that can not be played against. You will receive assurances that they are being fixed but they haven't been for 3 seasons at least. Some examples of OP unplayable combos:
50% of available dragons + Truth's charge (Any map)
Venomtail + Sparrowthorn (Any map)
Venomtail + Winterfloe (Any map)
Rimrock + Sparrowthorn (Any map)
Lunaveil + Sphere of wudeng (Ballistae Alley, but OP on any map)
Goldenclaw + chillblade (Any map)
Magmascale + chillblade (Chaos Unleashed / MOBA, but OP on any map)
Autobot + chillblade (Chaos Unleashed / MOBA)
Swiftwing + Unity mark (Chaos Unleashed / MOBA)
DarkOne + chill blade (Any map)
Dreadnaught + Rodar (Ballistae Alley)
Gravelurker + Truth's charge (Nether gate)
So skill really makes no difference in this game. Use any of the above combos to get lots of kills. Kills translate to higher ranking and more crystals, so you can buy more dragons. You can combine dragons to make more powerful dragons so you can get more kills, so continues the cycle. Some of you reading below will say I am a bad player complaining because I don not have the dragons listed below. Trust me, I have 10+ highest level (T4) dragons including 5 of the OP combos mentioned below. As a principle I refuse to use OP combos. So most of the time I am either getting killed or just defending against OP combos (using a defensive combo - see below).

As I mentioned, the above weapon combos are unplayable against, which means you have a 90% chance of losing against them. Only way to counter the Truth's charge weapon is to use the Chillblade weapon. So you will see lots of 'so called pros' running around with those combos. The only other way you can keep yourself from being killed every 1-2 minutes is to use a Tanglewing dragon + Rainmaker combo (my defensive combo).

The moderators and devs do not care about fixing the game and in fact are the people who use the OP combos. So if you are a new player, you are only helping them increase their ranking. What can you say about people whos only sense of importance is getting higher ranking using an OP combo on an online game... ;-)

This game allows duos (where two players can play together on same team). This just makes a broken game even more impossible to win. So two already good players will duo with OP combos making the odds of winning impossible. So you can bring complementary combos (e.g. two combos that almost slow enemy to a halt, combos that give unlimited health + mana, etc) So by the end of the game you will see they have killed like 15+ times each.

I have rarely seen mods on here who are sensible. The only qualification for being a mod on this game is to support the game no matter how broken it is and to of course prove it is not broken by using an OP combo. So that entails using the OP combo to show its broken and of course to keep telling players that nerfs and balances are coming. Trust me, they are not. 3 seasons ago, the DarkOne + Truth's charge was OP and we were told it was nerfed. Guess what, it still is OP and impossible to play against.

The game has 5 vs 5 PVP games mostly where you can use a preselected dragon + weapon combo. However it is so badly broken that it allows more than one player to use the same combo. So it is not unusual to see all 5 players using the same dragon or combo. So you will see games where you opposite team has 5 Dreadnaughts + Rodar's sceptre combo. That dragon is basically has the highest health and one of the highest damages in this game and can heal other dragons. Rodar's sceptre weapon increases your dragon's damage. So you know playing that game has like a 0.001% chance of winning. Hell, even if you have two Dreadnaughts in your team or enemy team the game becomes unbalanced since the 2 of those dragons will just outheal any damage you take or inflict.

Unlike other games, you can not pick what dragons or weapons you want to buy. 5000 in game crystals get you 3 random dragons out of 30+ possible dragons. 2500 crystals get you 3 random weapons out of 25+ possible weasopns. You do not know what dragon you will get and if you get duplicates you are stuck with them. You can sell or use duplicate dragons to create higher level dragons, but given most dragons except the OP ones are useless, you are just wasting your time. So you can grind for hours and let yourself be killed hundreds of times by OP combos in the hope that you can get enough crystals to get better dragons. But after all that effort, you do not control which dragon or weapon u get.
Despite all the above, if you still want to go ahead and try the game, my advice is that you try it for free. Do not waste any of your money on Titan's pass. Yes, they will say you get 4 times more crystals per game. Yes, they will say you will get access to all dragons and weapons but you already know you only ever need one of the 2 OP weapons and one of the above mentioned OP dragons. Better yet, keep making multiple accounts to get dragons + weapons. Since each new account gets 3 free dragons and weapons, you might get lucky with an account and get one of the OP combos above. The when u want to use that OP combo switch to that account to play, then create another account to try and get another OP combo... :-)

I hope this review helps you understand what you are getting into for this game and what you will get in return for your money. My advice is simple - do not invest your money or time in this game. Try any of the other games that this game tried to copy very badly - Leage of Legends, DOTA2, plenty others... At least there you will supporting a community that really cares.

reviewText:
Great concept but terrible execution. Game is unbalanced as hell, and bug ridden. Every update introduce new unbalanced items and new bugs. Old bugs drag on for years and the devs pay little attention to the quality. The game started on a good concept but was ruined by the developers due to ignorance and incompetence.

There were 3 maps in the game, 2 of which were rubbish and nobody used to play maps other than the chaos/moba map. Instead of improving the other maps, they would force players to play random maps so the un-performing maps would be played. In addition, the 3 maps play differently, and the dragon/weapon selection would perform very differently depending on the map. This means no matter how much effort you put into this game, the outcome of a match is randomized, depending on which map it puts you into. This gives you an idea of the kind of people they are.

The dragon and weapon selection is made before entering a game, and before you see any of your teammates or their selections. This means the player cannot choose combos that compliment the teammates. For a moba game this is horrible as players can never find a balanced team. Getting into a game with all support units against all attackers means a waste of 5-20 minutes of time.

The game had a skill shot pvp system where players had to aim their shots. To dumb it down in a failed attempt to attract players, it was chcanged to auto-aim. So instead of maneuvering and finding an opening to shoot the opponent, players now hold down the mouse button and sit idle until someone dies or escapes. The weapons/dragons that are harder to hit but hits harder, are now auto-aimed just like the easier to hit pee shooters. They were left un-balanced after auto aim was implemented 1-2 years ago. Very little attention was paid to balance the gameplay, as a matter of fact, that there are only about a quarter of the dragons/weapons that provide competitive performance. The rest create useless combos that cause teammates to hate you.

The game is plagued with hackers and lag bugs. Hackers would speed hack to win. They are reported by various over a year and no action would be taken. As a matter of fact, we would write support/report emails and would not hear answers for months, or ever in most cases. The lag bugs cause problem in gameplay where players take damage from the position they were in 1-2 seconds ago. Thus from your own computer, you'd think you are out of fire range but would still be taking damage. Furthermore, players are harmed by all kinds of invisble fireball, dragon breath that the server decided not to display.

It is not bad to try out the game to taste the concept of a lighter version of moba. But the game is far from good and the devs are less than competent to bring it up to standard.

reviewText:
Ok whre to start. This Game is quite different from the usual Dotalike games. Its faster and round are shorter with usally more kills.

The movement system is one of the biggest differences. There is no klick to move to location. Instead the dragon moves forward by either pressing shift or right mouse button. And it is always facing the mouse coursor. Space is used to move the dragon backwarts. There is no sideways movement.

Most skills are skillshot fiering in a specific pattern from your dragon. For example dragon btreah usally fires out of the fron (duh)

It less complex than other titles because it doesnt have items to buy in a match as you collect gold. Instead your skills will be determined by dragon and weapon choice for a total of 4 skills (two from each) and 2 additional spells like it it done in lol.

There is a huge selection of Dragons (about 30) and weapons (about the same amount) all of which play somewhat differently. You get 3 random dragons and weapons permanently as part of the tutorial. Other than that you have the usual rotation of free dragons and weapons.

The forced tutorial is one of the worst parts of the games. You have to go through serveral singleplayer mission + one match against the AI (a quite short one, just explaining the dota like mechanics) if you want to have full access to the multiplayer part. This should take about 45 minutes of gameplay and could be a letdown for some people.

The game is somewhat pay to win. You can pay for dragons  and weapons(randoms or specific ones) and only radom weapons ad dragons can be bought in ingame currency. Dragons can be upgraded by using 3 Tier1  or tier 2 dragons of the same type. They get some slight bonuses for it. Like 8% less mana cost and 4% more speed. Something about that line. It is achiveable by just playing but it will take quite a long time and you have to be lucky to get the right random dragons. Buying a tier 3 dragon costs about. 45€

There is a forging system which make weapons a bit stronger (something like 5% more damage, less cooldown, less mana cost) which can be payed for to get it as lot quicker.

And there is a rune system. which you can buy runes for with real money. (only random) Of couse tier2 and tier3 runes are available for non paying players too but they take a long times to craft it seems. (about 3 days for one tier 3 rune and one day for a tier 2 rune). Sadly i cannot asses how strong tier 3 runes are in comparison to tier 2 and 1. Here could be the part where the real pay to win could lie.

In total i would reccoment the game though. Its free and has dragons and it seems quite balanced and knowing the game is more important than bought 20% performance. You have to endure the tutorial though. Which isnt actually that bad.

reviewText: This game is fun and interesting, though it does tend to have a bit of a steep learning curve. The previous problem of it being pay to win seems to be largely fixed, since there is nothing other than cosmetic items that can't be obtained through simple hard work and chance. Even so, even with only three dragons, I'm finding that the game is still fun and has yet to lose any of its playability. The list of different dragons and weapons is long, and each combination makes the experience unique. No dragon seems to be better than another, as each one has its own individual characteristics, and thereforesome are better for certain roles than others.\n\nI recommend the game, and think it genuinely is fun. The developers do seem to listen to the players, and have adjusted the game to not have any exclusivity. Dragons and Titans obviously is not at the level of such games as League and Dota, so it should not be compared to them. However, as far as mobas go, it's a pretty great game to play. At the very least, you should give it a try.

reviewText:
A fantastic game, that genuinely has been given unfairly bad reviews.

The game is genuinely a unique ride, from start to finish. I've clocked in my fair share of Draconic combat, and thus far, I've genuinely enjoyed myself. There are most certainly aspects of it that are less than enjoyable, such as certain dragons feeling unstoppable, but in truth, every dragon can be beaten, but it's a matter of how well you play your own Dragon, and work with your teammates.

For a free title, the game has quite a massive selection of unique Dragons and weapons to choose from, though they are unlocked via random bundle packs that are purchased via in-game currency, called Gems. 3 dragons per hatching pack, 3 weapons per weapon pack. It certainly adds an air of eagerness to earn more Gems to try and unlock more dragons, as well as trying to get lucky to obtain a weapon you may have your eye on. The controls take a short bit of getting used to, but once you're used to them, they're surprisingly smooth, and let you maneuver your way through the skys fluently, while breathing various elements at your enemies, to deter them, as well as throwing out interesting techniques, unique to each dragon.

Is this game perfect? Definitely not. Is this game fun? Most certainly. Is it worth the asking price of 0 dollars? It got me to buy a founder pack, so hell yes it is. It frankly is a game worth trying, before passing judgement, and I don't regret any of the time I've spent in it so far.

reviewText:
The concept would be good, but the game has a lot of flaws. And by that, I mean, a LOT.

First of all, let's begin with the tutorial. It's one of the worst training levels I've ever seen. You will also get bored of it really quickly.
Then, I'd like to get into the controls: it's sometimes unclear, and some of the moves have two or more alternative functions aswell, meaning, that we may perform a specific attack without intention. Also, it's a mouse-cursor-following control, which is perfectly fine for games such as Diablo, Space Hack, Magicka or Path of Exile. For this game, I'd be more happy, if I got keyboard-controlling option.

reviewText:
It might not be the best game out there in this particular genre but that doesn't mean this is pure ♥♥♥♥ either. I believe this is a good game for people new to MOBA gaming. It could act as a gateway for casuals to turn into hard core players. I, for one, enjoy this game a lot. I haven't played much multiplayer (I'm hoping to get to that) but in single player, the rounds are pretty short (Chaos Unleashed takes about 20 minutes I believe or somewhat off). Others may find that a negative aspect of the game but for people like me who play this at school, I don't have an hour or more of uninterrupted school time to play just one match. I wouldn't have wanted to play an hour much either if I had the time.

The only major issue is that I feel like the game is pushing you to buy a Titan's Pass. You can only do Act 1 (a dissapointment since I wanted to finish the rest to get all the cool dragons they offered). After each match, you gain a painstakenly small amount of Runes which is fustrating because Dragon eggs are 5,000 and weapons are 2,500. About the eggs and weapons, you can only buy cases of three and have to rely on pure chance and luck to get that weapon/dragon you're looking for after countless hours spent just saving enough to get them in the first place. That problem just pushes you EVEN FURTHER to get a Titan's Pass. If only they made it a little bit more easier to earn stuff then I'd be content.
The next issue I'd like to address about this game is the Options menu. It's not very advanced. (It's an improvement from the Kong website.) You can't adjust the loudness of the sounds and music. Either you keep it or disable it all together.
